description: From Ancient Greek κιννάμωμον (kinnámōmon). Possible to be explained as “Chinese amōmum”, that word however is of unknown origin.

examples: Accipiunt sertas nardo florente coronasEt numquam fugiente rosa, multumque madentiInfudere comae quod nondum evanuit auraCinnamon externa nec perdidit aera terraeAdvectumque recens vicinae messis amomum.They received chaplets wreathed with the flowering nard, and the never-fading rose; and upon their dripping locks they poured forth plenteous cinnamon, that had not yet faded in the air nor lost its scent in a foreign land. The fresh amomum, too, of the adjacent harvests was brought.
